bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Henry P. Birmingham, January 30, 1925

div1.p: Kean offers his opinion on the accuracy of the Gorgas biography. He requests Birmingham's recollection of Gorgas' decision to retire.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Henry P. Birmingham, January 30, 1925
div1.opener:
January 30, 1925.
Col. H. P. Birmingham, USA, Ret.,
U.S. Soldiers Home,
Washington, D.C.
My dear Birmingham:
div1.p:
My mind has been taken back a good deal in the
last week to the old times by reading the biography of
General Gorgas by Mrs. Gorgas and Mr. Hendrick, and the
preparing of a review of it for The Military Surgeon.
The book is very entertainingly written but belongs more
to romance than to history. I was checking up some of
the facts this morning with General Ireland and we both
got to wondering when it was after General Gorgas' return
from South America and just before our declaration of war
with Germany that he spoke to the Secretary about his de-
sire to retire. Also why did he not do so? Was it
General Scott's opposition or our rupture of diplomatic
relations with Germany that prevented? Any statement
that you can give me with regard to this matter which is
now of some historical importance, will be much apprecia-
ted.
div1.closer:
Sincerely your friend, J. R. KEAN
Colonel, U.S. Army, Retired
Secretary-Treasurer JRK/W
